items.title: Iran says it's ready for war or talks as Trump weighs strike

featured_image.name: Abbas Araghchi, Iran's top diplomat, says Tehran is ready ...

items.description:
Iran's Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi declared Monday that Tehran is "fully prepared for war" but remains open to diplomacy with the United States, as President Donald Trump considers military intervention over the Iranian government's deadly crackdown on nationwide protests.

"The Islamic Republic of Iran is not seeking war but is fully prepared for war," Araghchi told a conference of foreign ambassadors in Tehran, broadcast on state television[1][2]. "We are also ready for negotiations, but these negotiations should be fair, with equal rights and based on mutual respect."

The statement came hours after Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One on Sunday that Iranian leaders had called him seeking to negotiate and that "a meeting is being set up"[3][4]. However, Trump warned the U.S. "may have to act before a meeting" due to the escalating violence against protesters.

items.title: Cuba rejects U.S. talks after Trump threatens oil cutoff

featured_image.name: Trump team puts a target on Cuba, with threats and oil ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump declared on Sunday that Cuba will no longer receive Venezuelan oil or money, demanding the Caribbean nation "make a deal, BEFORE IT IS TOO LATE" in a Truth Social post that drew a fiery rebuke from Cuban leadership. The threat marks an escalation of pressure on Cuba following the U.S. capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro on January 3.

Cuban President Miguel Díaz-Canel responded defiantly on X, stating, "Cuba is a free, independent and sovereign nation. No one tells us what to do."[1][2] He added that Cuba "does not attack; it has been attacked by the U.S. for 66 years, and it does not threaten; it prepares, ready to defend the homeland to the last drop of blood."[3][4]

On Monday, Díaz-Canel stated there are "no conversations with the US government except for technical contacts in the area of migration," while expressing openness to dialogue "founded on principles of sovereign equality, mutual respect, adherence to international law."[5][6]

items.title: Iran imposes near-total internet blackout as protests spread

featured_image.name: Iran in paralysis as internet blackout freezes banks and daily life

items.description:
The most widespread protests in years have swept across Iran over the past two weeks, with hundreds killed as authorities impose a near-total internet blackout and security forces escalate their crackdown on demonstrators demanding an end to clerical rule.

As the digital blackout enters its fifth day, the Human Rights Activists News Agency (HRANA) reported Monday that at least 544 people have been killed, including 496 protesters and 48 security personnel, while more than 10,600 individuals have been detained since demonstrations began on December 28[1][2]. Iran Human Rights, a Norway-based monitoring group, said unverified reports suggest the actual death toll could exceed 2,000, with much of the violence obscured by the communications shutdown[2].

items.title: Greenland seeks NATO defense umbrella as Trump refuses to rule out force

featured_image.name: Denmark's PM says Greenland showdown at 'decisive moment'

items.description:
Greenland's government announced on Monday that it will intensify efforts to ensure the Arctic territory's defense falls under NATO's framework, as US President Donald Trump doubled down on his ambition to acquire the island, refusing to rule out military force.

"All NATO member states, including the United States, have a common interest in the defence of Greenland," Greenland's coalition government said in a statement published on the Naalakkersuisut (government) website[1][2]. The move comes as Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One that "one way or the other, we are going to have Greenland"[3].

items.title: Apple picks Google's Gemini AI to power next-gen Siri

featured_image.name: Apple in talks to use Google's Gemini AI to power revamped Siri ...

items.description:
Apple officially confirmed Monday that it has selected Google's Gemini AI models to power the next-generation version of Siri, marking one of the most consequential partnerships between the two longtime rivals in the competitive artificial intelligence landscape.

"After careful evaluation, we determined that Google's technology provides the most capable foundation for Apple Foundation Models and we're excited about the innovative new experiences it will unlock for our users," Apple said in a statement shared with CNBC[1][2].

The announcement immediately boosted shares of Alphabet, Google's parent company, helping push it past the $4 trillion market capitalization threshold for the first time. Alphabet shares rose as much as 1.7% to $334.04 on Monday, with the company recently overtaking Apple to become the world's second-most valuable corporation behind Nvidia[3].

items.title: UK regulator opens first Online Safety Act probe into X

featured_image.name: UK regulator launches investigation into X over Grok sexualised imagery

items.description:
Britain's communications regulator Ofcom announced Monday that it has opened a formal investigation into Elon Musk's social media platform X over concerns that its AI chatbot Grok is being used to create and distribute sexualized deepfake images of women and children. The probe marks the first significant enforcement action under the UK's Online Safety Act targeting a major social media platform.

"There have been deeply concerning reports of the Grok AI chatbot account on X being used to create and share undressed images of people — which may amount to intimate image abuse or pornography — and sexualised images of children that may amount to child sexual abuse material," Ofcom said in a statement[1][2][3].

items.title: Alphabet becomes fourth company to hit $4 trillion valuation

featured_image.name: Alphabet hits $4 trillion market capitalization

items.description:
Alphabet broke through the $4 trillion market capitalization threshold on Monday, joining an exclusive club of companies to ever reach the valuation as investors bet heavily on the Google parent's dominance in artificial intelligence.

Shares rose as much as 1.7% to $334.04 on the news that Apple had selected Google's Gemini models to power the next generation of Siri, according to CNBC[1][2]. The announcement cemented Alphabet's position as Wall Street's second-most valuable company, surpassing Apple for the first time since 2019[3][4]. Only Nvidia, Microsoft, and Apple have previously crossed the $4 trillion mark[5][6].

items.title: Eutelsat orders 340 satellites from Airbus to rival Starlink

featured_image.name: Eutelsat extends Airbus contract for further low Earth orbit OneWeb satellites

items.description:
Eutelsat, the French-British satellite operator and sole European competitor to Elon Musk's Starlink, has ordered 340 low Earth orbit satellites from Airbus to expand and refresh its OneWeb constellation, the companies announced Monday.

The contract marks Eutelsat's first major industrial commitment since completing a €1.5 billion capital raise in late 2025, signaling the company's intent to aggressively pursue growth in the competitive LEO broadband market[1][2][3].

items.title: Meta taps ex Trump adviser Dina Powell McCormick as president

featured_image.name: Meta taps Dina Powell McCormick as president and vice chairman

items.description:
Meta Platforms announced Monday that Dina Powell McCormick, a former Goldman Sachs executive and deputy national security adviser under President Donald Trump, will join the company as president and vice chairman. The appointment marks the first time Meta has created a presidential role in the company's history.[1][2][3]

Powell McCormick, who served on Meta's board of directors from April to December 2025, will become part of the company's executive team and help guide its overall strategy. The move comes as Meta races to scale its AI infrastructure amid intense competition in the artificial intelligence sector.[1][2][4]

items.title: Uniper signs deal to import green ammonia from India

featured_image.name: India and Germany sign deals to deepen economic and security ties

items.description:
German energy company Uniper and India's AM Green Ammonia have finalized a long-term agreement for the supply of up to 500,000 tons of renewable ammonia annually, creating one of the first large-scale green fuel corridors between India and Europe[1][2][3].

The binding agreement, signed Monday in Ahmedabad in the presence of German Chancellor Friedrich Merz and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, marks a milestone in both countries' clean energy ambitions[4][5]. First deliveries are expected as early as 2028 from AM Green's 1 million-ton-per-year facility currently under construction in Kakinada, Andhra Pradesh[1][6].

items.title: China releases first software to sync time between Earth and Moon

featured_image.name: China unveils world's first timekeeping software for the ...

items.description: Scientists at China's Purple Mountain Observatory in Nanjing have released LTE440, the world's first publicly available software designed to synchronize time between Earth and the Moon. The Lunar Time Ephemeris package addresses a growing engineering challenge as space agencies prepare for more frequent and complex lunar missions in the coming decade.

items.title: Ancient galaxy was slowly strangled to death by its black hole

featured_image.name: Supermassive black hole starves host galaxy to death

items.description:
Astronomers have identified one of the earliest "dead" galaxies in the universe, revealing that its central supermassive black hole killed star formation not through a violent explosion but through repeated cycles of heating and expelling gas—a process researchers describe as "death by a thousand cuts."

The study, published January 11 in Nature Astronomy, used data from the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) and the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) to examine a galaxy designated GS-10578, nicknamed "Pablo's Galaxy" after the astronomer who first observed it in detail[1][2][3].

items.title: Germany's Uniper signs major green ammonia deal with India

featured_image.name: India and Germany sign deals to deepen economic and security ties

items.description:
German energy company Uniper and India's AM Green Ammonia have signed a long-term binding offtake agreement for up to 500,000 tons per year of renewable ammonia, marking what the companies call one of the first large-scale green fuel supply corridors between India and Europe[1][2][3].

The agreement was exchanged Monday in Ahmedabad in the presence of German Chancellor Friedrich Merz and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, underlining the deal's geopolitical significance as both nations seek closer collaboration on clean energy[2][4]. First shipments are expected as early as 2028 from AM Green's one-million-ton-per-year facility currently under construction in Kakinada, Andhra Pradesh[5][6].

items.title: China files plans for 200,000 satellites, dwarfing SpaceX

featured_image.name: SpaceX Alleges Close Approach of China-Launched Satellite to ...

items.description:
In a move that dramatically escalates competition for prime real estate in low Earth orbit, China has submitted plans to the International Telecommunication Union covering more than 200,000 satellites, according to ITU records released Sunday[1][2][3].

The filings, submitted in the final week of December 2025, dwarf any previous satellite constellation proposals and come just days after U.S. regulators approved an expansion of SpaceX's Starlink network[4][5].

items.title: Webb telescope finds black hole that slowly starved galaxy

featured_image.name: Webb telescope finds a 'dead galaxy' that stopped making ...

items.description: The James Webb Space Telescope has delivered a series of discoveries reshaping scientists' understanding of the early cosmos, including a "dead" galaxy starved by its own black hole, rare cosmic dust formed without typical ingredients, and a puzzling new class of galaxies that defy classification.

items.title: Unexplained shock wave around dead star puzzles astronomers

featured_image.name: Persistent shock wave around dead star puzzles astronomers

items.description:
Astronomers have discovered a colorful, persistent shock wave around a dead star that defies all known explanations, revealing what scientists describe as a first-of-its-kind cosmic phenomenon.

The white dwarf star RXJ0528+2838, located approximately 730 light-years from Earth, is surrounded by a glowing bow shock stretching roughly 3,800 times the distance between Earth and the Sun. The discovery, published Monday in the journal Nature Astronomy, has left researchers searching for answers to what they call a "mystery engine" powering the phenomenon[1][2].

items.title: Germany and India sign defense, AI deals to reduce China dependence

featured_image.name: India–Germany Partnership Gets New Lift As PM Modi, Chancellor ...

items.description:
German Chancellor Friedrich Merz and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Monday signed a series of agreements on defense, critical minerals, artificial intelligence, and education during Merz's first official visit to India, as both nations seek to reduce reliance on China and Russia amid shifting global alliances.

The two-day visit, taking place in Modi's home state of Gujarat, produced memorandums of understanding covering security cooperation, health sector collaboration, and the establishment of an AI innovation centre[1][2]. Modi announced visa-free transit for Indian citizens through Germany and invited German universities to open campuses in India as part of a new higher education roadmap[3][4].

items.title: Gold hits record high amid Fed probe, Iran unrest

featured_image.name: Gold prices hit record high past $4,600 amid Powell-Trump ...

items.description:
Gold surged past $4,600 per ounce for the first time on Monday, as investors rushed into safe-haven assets following the U.S. Justice Department's criminal investigation into Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and escalating violence from protests in Iran.

Spot gold jumped as much as 1.7% to reach a record high of $4,600.33 per ounce in Asian trading, according to Reuters[1][2]. Silver also climbed to an all-time high of $84.60 per ounce before settling around $83-84, extending a rally that has seen the white metal gain nearly 150% over the past year[3][4].

"So, between events in Iran, and potential U.S. involvement, and the (Fed) chair being the focus of a criminal probe... U.S. futures turned lower on the Powell news, which was a green light for gold to take a run higher," said Tim Waterer, chief market analyst at KCM Trade[1].

items.title: Wagner Moura becomes first Brazilian man to win Golden Globe

featured_image.name: Wagner Moura Wins Golden Globe for Best Actor in a Drama

items.description:
Brazilian actor Wagner Moura made Golden Globe history on Sunday night, becoming the first Brazilian man to win Best Actor in a Drama for his performance in "The Secret Agent," a political thriller set during Brazil's 1977 military dictatorship. The film also captured the Best Non-English Language Motion Picture award, cementing a triumphant night for Brazilian cinema at the Beverly Hilton.

"I was not prepared for this because I thought I was too old," Moura, 49, said during his acceptance speech, as reported by the Los Angeles Times[1]. The actor, who arrived on the red carpet in a white double-breasted jacket alongside his partner of nearly 30 years, Sandra Delgado, thanked his wife first in his remarks[2][3].

items.title: Japan launches first deep-sea rare earth mission amid China export curbs

featured_image.name: Japan to begin extracting deep-sea rare earths next year ...

items.description:
A Japanese research vessel departed Monday for a remote Pacific atoll to begin the world's first attempt to extract rare earths from deep-sea mud, as Tokyo accelerates efforts to reduce its dependence on China following Beijing's latest export restrictions.

The deep-sea scientific drilling ship Chikyu set sail from the port city of Shizuoka bound for Minamitori Island, approximately 1,900 kilometers southeast of Tokyo, for a month-long mission to retrieve mineral-rich sediment from depths of 6,000 meters, according to Reuters[1][2]. The voyage marks a first-of-its-kind effort to continuously lift rare-earth material from such depths to a ship.
